author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Stephanie Selby, ‘A Very Young Dancer’ Who Inspired Many, Dies at 56
description: A 1976 book of photographs and text traced her year at the School of American Ballet and made her famous. But a darker story lay underneath.
content: Stephanie Selby, who was the high-profile subject of “A Very Young Dancer,” a book that inspired a generation of would-be ballerinas and future dance stars, but who abruptly dropped out of the ballet world and disappeared from view, died on Feb. 3 in Cody, Wyo. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: D.C. and Joyce — Both Incomprehensible
description: Concussion versus incomprehension.
content: I was in an Uber on Broadway when suddenly the world began violently shaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: In Reversal, F.D.A. Delays Push for Shots for Children Under 5
description: The agency will wait for data on whether three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid vaccine are effective in young children after new, disappointing data.
content: WASHINGTON — In a striking reversal, federal regulators said on Friday that they would wait for data on how well three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine work in children younger than 5 before deciding whether to authorize the vaccine for that age group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter and Stacy Kranitz
title: Far From the Big City, New Economic Life
description: Incomes are low in small-town Tennessee, but so is the cost of living. That attraction could be a key to reviving many rural areas.
content: GAINESBORO, Tenn. — There is not much to suggest prosperity in Gainesboro, a hamlet of 920 in Tennessee’s Upper Cumberland region. Almost one in seven homes are vacant. One-quarter of the population lives in poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Emmanuel Macron in His Labyrinth
description: The French leader recounted his face-off with Vladimir Putin and dismissed Washington’s exchange of letters with Moscow, gambling that his diplomacy could pay off before April elections.
content: PARIS — Around a table much smaller than the 20-foot-long oval slab across which he confronted President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow, President Emmanuel Macron gathered a few journalists this week to confide that the crisis in Ukraine was taking up “more than half my time, the bulk of my time” because the world stands “at a tipping point” of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sasha Maslov
title: Running a Business Under the Shadow of War
description: “When you’re constantly thinking about invading Russians you’re not going to go buy a new phone, or a car, or a house.”
content: When I was flying to Kyiv from Odesa last month, I arrived at the airport to find a policewoman blocking an entrance to the terminal. A considerable crowd was gathered across the road. Apparently someone had called in a bomb threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: The U.S. men’s hockey team beats Canada in a preliminary game.
description: The two powerhouses had to cobble together rosters after the N.H.L. declined to allow its players to compete.
content: The United States’ stitched-together men’s hockey team turns out to have some pluck: It steered past Canada, which has won medals at the last three Olympic Games, in a preliminary game on Saturday, 4-2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The Traveling Trump Show
description: Pro-Trump rallies and conferences have taken on the flavor of religious revival, a mix between protest and party.
content: HIDALGO, Texas — Organizers of the three-day We Stand America gathering were clearly frustrated on Day Two: In an arena built to accommodate thousands of spectators, only a few hundred people had shown up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: We Aren’t in Vegas Anymore
description: Our society’s rules for gambling are becoming more internally consistent and more socially disastrous.
content: When future historians ponder the forces that unraveled the American social fabric between the 1960s and the 2020s, I hope they spare some time for one besetting vice in particular: our fatal impulse toward consistency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Remy Tumin
title: Golden years: Jacobellis, 36, and Baumgartner, 40, win in team snowboard cross.
description: Jacobellis won her second gold medal of the Beijing Games after leaving empty-handed in four previous Olympics. Baumgartner won his first Olympic medal.
content: Lindsey Jacobellis had gone 16 years in search of the Olympic gold medal that she squandered back in 2006, when she fell just before the finish line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Nice Fit: Joe Burrow Belongs to Everyone
description: In short order, the Bengals quarterback has achieved a crossover appeal that has inspired Joe Namath comparisons.
content: Joe Burrow strode into Arrowhead Stadium two Sundays ago for the A.F.C. championship game clad in a black turtleneck, rimless sunglasses, a blinding diamond pendant — and a Sherpa jacket, decked with hearts, that would soon become an internet curiosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: What Comes Before the Fall?
description: Mary Lou Guizzo’s delightful Saturday grid will catch your fancy.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a brisk challenge from Mary Lou Guizzo, who has “hit for the cycle” for The New York Times, meaning that she has constructed at least one puzzle on every day of the week (as well as a bonus variety puzzle in 2016). Her themed grids are very inventive and often come with visual components, but I’ll gladly work on a themeless construction like this one, which is full of interesting references and bright wordplay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Anna Schaverien
title: Eric Adams Is Pushing a Plan to Speed Up Buses. Will It Work?
description: Mayor Eric Adams has promised 150 miles of new bus lanes in New York City, but some drivers and businesses say they have created headaches in the past.
content: The B41 bus rolls forward in fits and starts. Cars cut in front of it and dollar vans and delivery trucks block access to the curb to pick up passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Lars Eighner, Who Wrote Eloquently of Being Homeless, Dies at 73
description: His 1993 memoir, “Travels With Lizbeth,” is considered a classic of the genre and brought him fame, but not fortune.
content: Lars Eighner, who vividly recounted his experiences with being homeless in “Travels With Lizbeth,” a book widely regarded as one of the finest memoirs of recent decades, died on Dec. 23 in Austin, Texas. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Julie Saul, Effervescent Manhattan Gallerist, Is Dead at 67
description: She promoted photographers like Sally Gall and Arne Svenson, and she later broadened her gallery’s scope to include multimedia artists like Maira Kalman and Roz Chast.
content: Julie Saul, an energetic and outspoken longtime Manhattan gallerist who championed, often fiercely, photographers like Sally Gall, Andrew Bush and Arne Svenson, as well as multimedia artists like Sarah Anne Johnson, Maira Kalman and Roz Chast, died on Feb. 4 at her family’s home in Tampa, Fla. She was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: U.S. overnight coverage includes ice dancing and skeleton.
description: Ice dancers bring the drama to the rink at 6 a.m.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Saturday. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Making ‘Dinobabies’ Extinct: IBM’s Push for a Younger Work Force
description: Documents released in an age-discrimination case appear to show high-level discussion about paring the ranks of older employees.
content: In recent years, former IBM employees have accused the company of age discrimination in a variety of legal filings and press accounts, arguing that IBM sought to replace thousands of older workers with younger ones to keep pace with corporate rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Valieva Is ‘Innocent and Clean,’ Her Coach Declares
description: A hearing on Sunday could determine if the star Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva will be allowed to continue competing at the Olympics.
content: Kamila Valieva, the Russian figure skating star at the center of a doping scandal threatening to overshadow the Beijing Olympics, returned to the ice at a practice rink on Saturday, hitting quadruple jump after quadruple jump as she prepared for an event from which she may soon be barred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Battles Putin by Disclosing His Next Possible Moves
description: Declassified information is part of a campaign to complicate what officials say are Russia’s plans to invade Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — After decades of getting schooled in information warfare by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the United States is trying to beat the master at his own game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Harris Says Replacing Lead Pipes Is a Priority, Despite Limited Funding
description: Some civil rights leaders have grown frustrated with the lack of action behind administration proposals that would help Black and Latino communities.
content: NEWARK — Schkeema Troutman had just started describing the many difficulties of trying to raise a family in a city with high levels of lead in its drinking water when Vice President Kamala Harris noticed the mother of three was not being heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Why Was Dave Chappelle at a Village Council Meeting in Ohio?
description: The comedian helped quash a plan for affordable housing in Yellow Springs, Ohio, this week by threatening to pull a multimillion-dollar investment.
content: Dave Chappelle has had an outsize influence on Yellow Springs, Ohio, in recent years, attracting A-list celebrities to outdoor comedy shows and parties he organized in the village, which is home to some 3,700 people. But this week, he exchanged glitz and glamour for the staid procedures of a Village Council meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: In Ottawa Protests, a Pressing Question: Where Were the Police?
description: They were vastly outnumbered, experts say, and unprepared for the sophisticated tactics, discipline and logistical abilities of the protesters.
content: OTTAWA — Steps from Canada’s Parliament buildings, a sprawling festival erupted on Saturday. D.J.s played music for crowds dancing at intersections, singers belted out songs from an improvised stage and protesters’ trucks still blocked the streets, blowing their horns to cheers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Musk Boosts His Plans for Mars, but Many Hurdles Remain
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 12, 2022.
content: “We need to seize the opportunity and do it as quickly as possible. I want to be frank: Civilization is feeling a little fragile these days.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evelyn N. Farkas
title: We Underestimated Putin Once. We Can’t Make That Mistake Again.
description: The Biden administration must treat Russia as a rogue state and aggressively isolate Moscow.
content: The White House on Friday came out with its starkest warning yet on the threat facing Ukraine, saying Moscow could invade any day now. The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, stressed there was no way to predict what President Vladimir Putin of Russia might do — but history shows we should not underestimate Mr. Putin’s willingness to violate another country’s sovereignty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Is the Metaverse Just Marketing?
description: The metaverse doesn’t quite exist yet. But the hype still matters.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Slow Fashion Meets Melrose Place
description: Emily Bode expands her men’s wear brand into the heart of Los Angeles’s shopping district.
content: The facade of the new Bode store in Los Angeles — bone white plaster, two windows obscured by humdrum vertical blinds, signage worthy of a municipal building — is discreet to the point of invisible. It could easily be a small-town haberdashery from a bygone era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Rick Caruso, Billionaire Developer, Jumps Into Los Angeles Mayor’s Race
description: The longtime civic leader fits the profile of successful power brokers in the city’s past. Will that kind of résumé succeed in the present?
content: Rick J. Caruso, a billionaire real estate developer and longtime civic figure, jumped into the race for mayor of Los Angeles on Friday, shaking up a crowded field for the top job in the nation’s second-largest city after more than a decade of flirting with a run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Building Is Offering Covid Tests, but Not for Young Children. Is That Legal?
description: Co-op boards are required by law to treat all shareholders equally, meaning they can’t cherry pick who gets a Covid-19 test.
content: Q: The president of my co-op board has offered free at-home Covid-19 antigen tests to all residents ages 5 and up. Each household received two tests per person, so a family with two adults and two teenagers received eight tests. But a family with two adults and two toddlers only received four tests because of the age restriction. This seems inequitable to me. Shouldn’t all households be treated fairly and receive the same number of tests per person, regardless of age?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Judges’ snowboarding scores continue to fuel controversy.
description: An NBC analyst roasted the judges after Ayumu Hirano’s second halfpipe run, saying they had “grenaded” their credibility.
content: For a brief moment on Thursday night, social media was ready to throw down in support of the snowboarder Ayumu Hirano of Japan. On his second run, Hirano became the first competitor in an Olympic Games to land a triple cork — three flips performed on a rotation while grabbing the board — as part of what the NBC analyst Todd Richards called “the best run that’s ever been done in the halfpipe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Sleeping in Pieces
description: Are sleep disruptions here to stay?
content: “Hello from the intermission,” my friend Ali texted me at 6:37 the other morning. Ali is sleeping in shifts, first midnight until 4:30 or 5 a.m., when she rises for an hour or two of Wordle and TV, then back to bed for a second installment, which concludes sometime around 9. The only problem with this arrangement, as she sees it, is that sleeping takes longer than it would if she knocked out her hours consecutively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: An old falsehood resurfaces: that Justin Trudeau is Fidel Castro’s son.
description: Some conspiracy theorists have pointed to a resemblance between Mr. Castro and Mr. Trudeau. But the facts don’t add up.
content: Misinformation has been a key weapon wielded by Canada’s protest movement, and critics of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau have returned to one simmering falsehood: that Mr. Trudeau is the love child of the former Cuban leader Fidel Castro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and James Hill
title: Curling’s Scottish Soundtrack, Delivered by Bagpipers from Beijing
description: An Olympic arena’s house band is devoted to a sound, not stones. “I honestly don’t know much about the rules,” one musician said. “What we like most is the bagpipes.”
content: BEIJING — The curling arena darkened and strobe lights blotted the ice. A band of bagpipers marched in almost like a vision from another time, or at the very least, another continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chencho Dema and Mike Ives
title: ‘Improbable Journey’: How a Movie From Tiny Bhutan Got an Oscar Nod
description: “Lunana: A Yak in the Classroom” was filmed on a shoestring budget in a remote Himalayan village. It’s now an Academy Award nominee, a first for Bhutan.
content: THIMPHU, Bhutan — As a crew of 35 people prepared to make a movie in Bhutan’s remote Lunana Valley, they faced a slew of seemingly insurmountable obstacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Katie Rogers
title: Biden, a Veteran of Supreme Court Fights, Ponders His Own Historic Pick
description: President Biden spent decades in the Senate and presided over the transformation of Supreme Court fights into hyperpartisan affairs. Now he is pushing to lower the temperature for his own nominee.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is staying up late in the White House residence, poring over the biographies of four potential Supreme Court nominees and cases they have decided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Hill
title: Artistry and Grace: See Ice Dancing’s Opening Night
description: Twenty-three teams are bringing power and passion to the ice. Take a look at these photos from the competition in Beijing.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Anupreeta Das
title: Cisco Has Discussed Deal for Software Company Splunk
description: No deal is currently on the table, according to two people familiar with the talks, but Cisco could pay more than $20 billion, one said.
content: Cisco Systems, the technology conglomerate, has held discussions with the software company Splunk about buying it, although no deal is currently on the table, two people familiar with the matter told The New York Times on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Meet Me at 3 A.M. For a Cup of Coffee.
description: The pandemic has allowed some people to return to a former way of sleeping: in segments.
content: About a year into the pandemic, Marcela Rafea began waking up consistently at 3 a.m., her mind racing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: For N.F.L. Perfection, a Steep Price
description: Nick Buoniconti, Jim Kiick and Jake Scott, of the undefeated 1972 Miami Dolphins, were each found to have C.T.E., the brain disease linked to head hits, bringing to six the number of players diagnosed from that team.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — On a sunny January day nearly 50 years ago, Nick Buoniconti, Jim Kiick and Jake Scott ran off the field at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum not just as Super Bowl champions, but as part of the only team in N.F.L. history to complete a perfect season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Scientists prepare for the next phase of learning to live with Covid.
description: As the Omicron wave subsides in regions across the world, more governments, politicians and health officials are telling us that it’s time to start “living with the virus.”
content: As the Omicron wave subsides in regions across the world, more governments, politicians and health officials are telling us that it’s time to start “living with the virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Marriage Made Me Let Go of My Dreams. Good.
description: What if joy is found in not getting exactly what we want?
content: At the age of 6 I declared that I would one day become a pastor. It might seem odd that someone barely able to read chapter books would commission himself to proclaim the word of the Lord. But I come from a long line of preachers. If you visit the cemetery on the plantation that hosts the graves of my mother’s side of the family, you will see names with “Reverend” etched into the tombstones going all the way back to the 1800s. My ancestors, slaves and later tenant farmers, would leave the cotton fields after a long day of work, put on their best pair of overalls and preach the good news to other weary Black folks looking for a modicum of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: After Nearly 58 Years, Pennsylvania Police Solve Killing of 9-Year-Old Girl
description: On Sundays and holidays, the victim’s mother ended a prayer with a plea: “Please help the Pennsylvania State Police find the man that hurt my daughter.”
content: On March 18, 1964, Marise Ann Chiverella left for school, carrying canned goods to give to her teacher, a nun at St. Joseph’s Parochial School in Hazleton, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: A Russian figure skater’s failed test casts shadow over the Games.
description: Leaping and spinning at high speed on Monday night, Kamila Valieva of Russia became the first female figure skater to complete a quad — a jump with four rotations — at the Olympics.
content: Leaping and spinning at high speed on Monday night, Kamila Valieva of Russia became the first female figure skater to complete a quad — a jump with four rotations — at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: The Supreme Court rejects a bid by New York teachers to block a city vaccine mandate.
description: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected an emergency request that it consider an appeal by a group of New York City teachers seeking to block a vaccine mandate over what they said was a discriminatory religious exemption policy.
content: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected an emergency request that it consider an appeal by a group of New York City teachers seeking to block a vaccine mandate over what they said was a discriminatory religious exemption policy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s what’s happening with the trucker-led protests in Canada and a copycat protest in Paris.
description: Canadian police moved in on Saturday  to clear protesters at a vital bridge in Windsor, Ontario, that connects to the United States, and the police in Paris fired tear gas at copycat demonstrators blocking traffic on the Champs-Élysées.
content: Canadian police moved in on Saturday  to clear protesters at a vital bridge in Windsor, Ontario, that connects to the United States, and the police in Paris fired tear gas at copycat demonstrators blocking traffic on the Champs-Élysées.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes figure skating, monobob and skiing.
description: The bobsledders Elana Meyers Taylor and Kaillie Humphries compete for the United States in a new event.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with events in figure skating, bobsled and Alpine skiing. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Celarier
title: Are Activist Short Sellers Misunderstood?
description: A government investigation and proposed rules aim to rein in investors who talk down stocks. But some argue abuse by activist short sellers isn’t as common as believed.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: My Workplace Romance Was a Brilliant Mistake
description: Strong feelings can develop, even within the confines of strong — and necessary — boundaries.
content: When people ask me how I met my husband, I tend to mumble something about how we met “at work.” If there are follow-up questions, I eventually confess that I was his boss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Slave Trade Didn’t Come Out of Nowhere
description: Unraveling the characteristics of race today requires an understanding of history.
content: In my Jan. 29 newsletter, I wrote a little about the development of the domestic slave trade in the United States, apropos of my Sunday Review story on the SlaveVoyages database and the effort to measure and quantify the trans-Atlantic slave trade. That newsletter focused on the economics of slave-based cultivation and how it led inevitably to a surplus of enslaved people who could be sold at great profit after the United States ended its participation in the trans-Atlantic trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Can Democrats See What’s Coming?
description: They need to realize that America’s future does not lie in Europe’s past.
content: If you had to distill the ambitions of the Democratic Party down to a single word, you might well choose “Denmark.” But “France” would also work. Or “Germany.” Any Western European nation, really, with the social insurance options many of us envy: universal health care and affordable child care, to name but a few. Much of modern American liberalism is designed to close those gaps, to build here what already exists there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Schama
title: Radicals Used to Make Change. Then Social Media Happened.
description: Gal Beckerman’s “The Quiet Before” examines the births of social movements from the 17th century to the present day.
content: THE QUIET BEFOREOn the Unexpected Origins of Radical IdeasBy Gal Beckerman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Eric Lipton
title: Selling Trump: A Profitable Post-Presidency Like No Other
description: Much as he did while in the White House, Donald Trump has thoroughly blurred the lines between his political ambitions and his business interests, with a wide-ranging set of moneymaking ventures.
content: In early December, Donald J. Trump put on a tuxedo and boarded the private jet of a scrap-metal magnate and crypto-miner for a short flight across Florida, touching down at an airport in Naples. There, a long red carpet marked the pathway into a Christmas-decorated hangar filled with supporters of Mr. Trump who had paid $10,000 to $30,000 for the privilege of attending a party and taking a photo with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Walmart says vaccinated workers no longer have to wear masks in most states.
description: The retailer said it was taking action after governors from Connecticut to California ended mask mandates recently.
content: Walmart said on Friday that fully vaccinated employees would no longer have to wear masks unless state or local rules required it. The change is effective immediately, the giant retailer said in a memo to its staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: While several states lifted mask mandates, public health officials said not so fast: The week in Covid news.
description: States governed by Democrats across the country began reversing mask mandates this week, but federal officials warned against doing so and school districts were left grappling with what to do.
content: States governed by Democrats across the country began reversing mask mandates this week, but federal officials warned against doing so and school districts were left grappling with what to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: In the Kamila Valieva Story, Echoes of a Dark Era of Doping
description: Decades after East Germany gave steroids to its athletes and just a few years after Russia’s doping program was exposed, the Olympic Games are again roiled by scandal.
content: The announcement that Kamila Valieva, the 15-year-old Russian figure skating star, had tested positive for a banned substance echoed another dark Olympic era. And it sent a chilling reminder that female athletes in certain sports have long been considered disposable in countries that support state-sponsored doping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: ‘I Had Never Felt Worse’: Long Covid Sufferers Are Struggling With Exercise
description: And experts have some theories as to why.
content: When Natalie Hollabaugh tested positive for Covid-19 in March 2020, her recovery felt extremely slow. Eighteen months later, she was still suffering from a litany of symptoms, including fatigue, shortness of breath, headaches and joint pain. She saw a cardiologist and a pulmonologist, who both ruled out other health problems, she said. And they advised her to start exercising, suggesting that some of her symptoms may have been a result of being out of shape. So Ms. Hollabaugh dutifully began using an exercise bike, speed walking on a treadmill and walking her dogs several miles a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski, Katie Rogers and Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Pulls Most Diplomats From Kyiv as Tensions Mount
description: Western officials made another diplomatic push on Saturday to dissuade President Vladimir V. Putin from invading Ukraine.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that invading Ukraine would result in “swift and severe” costs to Russia, diminish his country’s standing and cause “widespread human suffering,” the White House said on Saturday, as Western officials made a forceful diplomatic push to dissuade Mr. Putin from pressing forward with an attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Zoology and Org Charts
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Greetings, booklings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: After Pak and Beeple, What’s Next for NFT Collectors? Art Made With a Paintbrush
description: Now crypto collectors are investing in something more tangible, and traditional, like paintings and sculpture. And art dealers are rushing to woo them.
content: Felix Xu started his NFT art collection by purchasing a Chromie Squiggle, generated by an algorithm. Today, Xu, a 29-year-old Chinese tech executive, has more than 3,000 blockchain-based collectibles. But there is a hole burning in his crypto wallet that he would like to fill with real paintings. His budget stretches toward $500,000 and he is already on the wait-list for in-demand artists who use paint and moving brushes like Zhang Zipiao .
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The Importance of a Second Chance
description: Americans love a good redemption story, but is it always deserved?
content: Sunday is the Super Bowl, often the most watched television program in America each year. In fact, Super Bowl XLIX in 2015, between the New England Patriots and the Seattle Seahawks, is the second-most watched broadcast of all time in the U.S. (after the Apollo 11 moon landing in 1969).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Black Authors Shake Up Brazil’s Literary Scene
description: Young Black Brazilians are publishing on their own terms, achieving the critical and commercial success that eluded past generations of writers from marginalized communities.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Itamar Vieira Júnior, whose day job working for the Brazilian government on land reform took him deep into the impoverished countryside, knew next to nothing about the mainstream publishing industry when he put the final touches on a novel he had been writing on and off for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Damien Cave
title: Blinken Says U.S. Has a ‘Long-Term Future’ in the Pacific Islands
description: The secretary of state promised a new embassy in the Solomon Islands and help on issues like climate change, as Washington vies with Beijing for influence in the region.
content: NADI, Fiji — As the first U.S. secretary of state to visit Fiji in 36 years, Antony J. Blinken wanted to make clear that jetting here to meet with Pacific island leaders was just the start of an expanding American presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: A Million More Trees for New York City: Leaders Want a Greener Canopy
description: The city’s five borough presidents are also urging the mayor to honor a pledge to spend 1 percent of the municipal budget on parks.
content: When Mayor Eric Adams named a commissioner last week to oversee New York’s parks department, he spoke of how important the city’s green spaces were for recreation and contemplation, especially during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: A Beijing Games first: Real snow in Zhangjiakou.
description: Natural snowfall is scarce in the region where the events are taking place. The skiing and snowboarding sites have been using artificial snow.
content: China’s water-scarce capital went to enormous lengths to make enough artificial snow for the Winter Olympics. But on Saturday morning, athletes in the mountains woke up to the real deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Pennsylvania Police Are Sued After Murder Cases Collapse
description: Robert Thomas and Cheron Selton were charged in Allegheny County for killing five people. After four years of pretrial detention, one had charges dismissed and the other was acquitted at trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Can’t keep up with the triumphs and heartbreak? Here’s what’s still to come.
description: In the final week of the Beijing Games, a host of stars are competing in anticipated events.
content: The two weeks-plus duration of the Olympic Games tends to have a certain rhythm. And it’s in the final week that fatigue can start to set in. So many great performances. So much triumph and heartbreak. How much more can we take?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: As Violence Rises in the West Bank, Settler Attacks Raise Alarm
description: Attacks by settlers and Palestinians have both reached a five-year high. But unlike Palestinian suspects, violent settlers are rarely prosecuted.
content: BURIN, West Bank — The Israeli settlers streamed down the hill toward Palestinian farmland, some waving sticks, some throwing stones, all masked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Flouted Presidential Records Law. Will He Face Consequences?
description: The former president’s telephone habits and penchant for destroying papers have investigators examining the Presidential Records Act and other statutes.
content: WASHINGTON — While he was president, Donald J. Trump was known to destroy, tear up, remove and even flush White House documents down the toilet. He often eschewed the White House switchboard, using his own cellphone or those of his aides to communicate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wolcott
title: Reality Stars Are Just Like Us
description: In “True Story,” the sociologist Danielle J. Lindemann parses the enduring appeal and effect of the TV genre.
content: TRUE STORY What Reality TV Says About Us By Danielle J. Lindemann
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Yes, There’s a Romance to Marriage
description: And parenthood doesn’t have to be where passion goes to die.
content: It’s difficult to write about a good marriage without sounding like a complete jerk: If you only write about the highs it comes off as fake, or as if you’re trying to compensate for your private faults. It also leaves you open to those who might crow if, someday, your relationship ends up cratering. Think about those “Real Housewives” vow renewals that quickly wind up being followed by divorce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Change of Heart
description: David Steinberg’s Sunday puzzle hits us in a sweet spot.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid, like yesterday’s, is from a longstanding member of The Times’s constructor community: David Steinberg. He’s been making grids for every day of the week — as well as variety puzzles — since 2011, when he made his debut at 14 years old. According to its print introduction, this puzzle is his 101st.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: Business Booms at Kroger-Owned Grocery Stores, but Workers Are Left Behind
description: A number of the stores’ nearly 500,000 employees have reported being homeless, receiving government food stamps or relying on food banks.
content: When Enrique Romero Jr. finishes his shift fulfilling online orders at a Fred Meyer grocery store in Bellingham, Wash., he often walks to a nearby plasma donation center. There, he has his blood drained, and a hydrating solution is pumped into his veins, a process that leaves him tired and cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: Seen ‘Inventing Anna’? Here’s What It Gets Right (and Wrong)
description: A reporter who has followed the scammer Anna Sorokin, a.k.a. Anna Delvey, for years watched the new Netflix series about the scandal. The reporter has thoughts.
content: The new Netflix series “Inventing Anna,” about the con artist Anna Sorokin, better known as Anna Delvey, includes a playful disclaimer that leaves a lot of room for interpretation. “This whole story is completely true,” it reads. “Except for all the parts that are totally made up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Recent studies underscore the dangers of pregnancy complications for unvaccinated women with Covid.
description: Two new reports lay out the added difficulties that unvaccinated women with Covid have during pregnancy and childbirth, adding to research showing that they face elevated risks.
content: Two new reports lay out the added difficulties that unvaccinated women with Covid have during pregnancy and childbirth, adding to research showing that they face elevated risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: When Working for Racial Justice Means Taking Black History Month Off
description: The period when firms are ordinarily flooded with requests instead became a reminder, for clients, that this work should persist all throughout the year.
content: Rhonda Broussard spent two decades performing with West African dance groups in her free time. She would wait around all year for gigs — until February when her calendar was jammed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Lia Thomas Is Cleared to Swim at N.C.A.A. Championships
description: The organizing body in college sports said that implementing new testosterone testing rules in the middle of the season would be unfair to transgender athletes.
content: The N.C.A.A. on Friday cleared the way for the swimmer Lia Thomas, a transgender woman who has turned in the top times in the country in two events, to compete in the N.C.A.A. championships next month, saying that implementing new rules for testosterone testing in the middle of the season would be unfair to transgender athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Steven Lee Myers
title: China’s Hockey Squad Shows a Powerhouse’s Weakness: Team Sports
description: The Chinese team in the Beijing Olympics could shock the Games. But it is more likely to underscore how little infrastructure the country has for team sports.
content: BEIJING — There may be no team at the Olympic Games with more potential to shock — or shame — than China’s men’s hockey squad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Officers fire tear gas at protesters blocking traffic on the Champs-Élysées.
description: Hundreds of vehicles emulating the “Freedom Convoy” protests in Canada evaded police checkpoints around Paris, but the police vowed a firm response.
content: PARIS — The police fired tear gas at demonstrators blocking traffic on the Champs-Élysées in central Paris on Saturday, after hundreds of vehicles emulating the “Freedom Convoy” protests in Canada evaded police checkpoints around the French capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Giulia Heyward
title: Teachers Tackle Black History Month, Under New Restrictions
description: In states where laws now limit classroom discussions about race and discrimination, many teachers are watching what they say, and are more anxious about their jobs.
content: In rural New Hampshire, a Spanish teacher took down a “Black Lives Matter” sign in her classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: At Beijing Press Conferences, the Questions Tell Their Own Story
description: There were 12 questions asked in English on Saturday, and 11 were about a doping scandal. There were seven questions asked in Chinese, and they were about, basically, anything else.
content: BEIJING — The first question at the Olympics daily news conference on Saturday came from a German reporter, and anyone could have guessed what he would ask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Coronavirus cases spiked, and then sputtered, at the Winter Games.
description: Numbers have fallen off sharply since peaking on Feb. 2.
content: As athletes, journalists and others prepared to travel to Beijing amid the Omicron surge, and China carried out sweeping lockdowns to keep the highly contagious coronavirus variant from spreading, the world held its breath to see if the Winter Games would plunge into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A U.S. Olympic snowboarding coach is under investigation for sexual misconduct.
description: Peter Foley denied the accusations that were made by a former athlete.
content: A U.S. Olympic snowboarding coach is under investigation after a former athlete accused him of inappropriate behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jugal K. Patel, Eleanor Lutz and Vivek Shankar
title: Where the Canadian Trucker Protests Are Happening
description: Truck drivers protesting vaccine mandates parked their trucks in cities across Canada, blocking traffic and disrupting the flow of goods between the nation and the U.S.
content: Truck drivers protesting vaccine mandates parked their trucks in cities across Canada, blocking traffic and disrupting the flow of goods between the nation and the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames and Emmanuel Morgan
title: Super Bowl LVI by the Numbers
description: On Sunday, Matthew Stafford and the Rams take on Joe Burrow and the Bengals in the 56th Super Bowl.
content: On Sunday, Matthew Stafford and the Rams take on Joe Burrow and the Bengals in the 56th Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: You’ll See Monobob Soon. What Is It?
description: For one thing, it’s an opportunity for American bobsledders like Elana Meyers Taylor and Kaillie Humphries.
content: For one thing, it’s an opportunity for American bobsledders like Elana Meyers Taylor and Kaillie Humphries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke-Williams and Rex Sakamoto
title: Turmoil in Canada Intensifies as Protests Threaten Economy
description: Despite a mass of protesters demanding an end to vaccine mandates and coronavirus restrictions in Canada, polls have shown that a majority of Canadians support the pandemic health measures.
content: Despite a mass of protesters demanding an end to vaccine mandates and coronavirus restrictions in Canada, polls have shown that a majority of Canadians support the pandemic health measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters, The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Paris Police Fire Tear Gas to Disperse Banned Protest Convoy
description: Hundreds of vehicles emulating the “Freedom Convoy” demonstrations in Canada descended on the French capital to protest the government’s vaccine pass and other policies.
content: Hundreds of vehicles emulating the “Freedom Convoy” demonstrations in Canada descended on the French capital to protest the government’s vaccine pass and other policies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 12, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 12, 2022.
content: Because of a production error, an article on Friday about President Biden’s prediction that he would have Republican support for his Supreme Court nominee included columns of type that were out of order.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rise in Book Bans and Censorship
description: Readers discuss complaints against “Maus,” “To Kill a Mockingbird,” “Beloved” and other books.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
